preface.p: Pakistan financial and banking legal corpus — a machine-readable consolidation of key provisions from the Banking Companies Ordinance 1962, the Microfinance Institutions Ordinance 2001, the State Bank of Pakistan Act 1956, the Payment Systems and Electronic Fund Transfers Act 2007, SBP Raast Regulations 2021, SBP Regulations for Electronic Money Institutions 2019, and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947.

This corpus is provided for compliance-tensor evaluation within the Momentum EZ stack. It does not replace the authoritative gazette text. All monetary thresholds reflect the position as of 1 January 2024 unless otherwise noted.

content.p: No banking company shall carry on banking business in Pakistan unless it has a minimum paid-up capital (net of losses) as prescribed by the State Bank from time to time.
As per SBP BSD Circular of 2022, the Minimum Capital Requirement (MCR) for scheduled commercial banks is:

item.p: For all scheduled commercial banks (conventional and Islamic): paid-up capital (free of losses) of not less than PKR 10,000,000,000 (ten billion Pakistani Rupees).
Foreign bank branches: minimum assigned capital of USD 300,000,000 (three hundred million United States Dollars) or equivalent, maintained as head office capital assigned to the Pakistan branch.

content.p: The State Bank may, by notification in the official gazette, revise the minimum capital requirement. Any banking company failing to meet the MCR shall be subject to restrictions on dividend distribution, branch expansion, and new business lines, and may have its licence suspended or cancelled under section 14.
Every banking company shall maintain with the State Bank a cash reserve computed as a percentage of its time and demand liabilities in Pakistan.
The current Cash Reserve Requirement is 5% of total demand and time liabilities (DTL), to be maintained on a daily average basis over a bi-weekly period.

Demand liabilities include current deposits, demand portions of savings deposits, margins held against letters of credit or guarantees, and any other liability payable on demand. Time liabilities include fixed deposits, time portions of savings deposits, borrowings from other institutions, and any other liability payable after a notice period or at a fixed date.

Failure to maintain the required CRR on any day of the maintenance period shall attract a penalty at a rate equal to three percentage points above the prevailing SBP policy rate, applied to the shortfall amount on a daily basis.
In addition to the CRR under section 14, every banking company shall maintain liquid assets as a percentage of its time and demand liabilities.
The Statutory Liquidity Requirement currently stands at a minimum of 18% of time and demand liabilities, to be maintained in the form of:

item.p: cash in excess of CRR;
gold valued at a price not exceeding the current market price;
Government of Pakistan Market Treasury Bills (MTBs);
Pakistan Investment Bonds (PIBs);
Ijara Sukuk issued by the Government of Pakistan;
any other approved security as notified by SBP from time to time.

content.p: Penalties for SLR shortfall are computed on the same basis as CRR shortfall penalties under section 14.

section.heading: Restrictions on loans to directors and related parties

content.p: No banking company shall:

item.p: grant any loan or advance on the security of its own shares;

grant unsecured loans or advances to any of its directors, or to any firm or company in which any of its directors is interested as partner, director, or guarantor, or to any individual in respect of whom any of its directors is a guarantor;
grant to any single person or group of persons aggregate loans, advances, or credit facilities exceeding 30% of the bank's equity as per SBP Prudential Regulations (single borrower exposure limit);
grant to any group of connected persons aggregate exposure exceeding 50% of the bank's equity (group exposure limit).

content.p: Any loan or advance made in contravention of this section shall be recoverable forthwith, and the directors who sanctioned such loan shall be jointly and severally liable to the banking company for any loss arising therefrom.
Every banking company shall maintain a capital adequacy ratio (CAR) in accordance with the Basel III framework as implemented by SBP through its Prudential Regulations and circulars.
The minimum capital adequacy requirements are:

item.p: Minimum Common Equity Tier 1 (CET-1) ratio: 6.0% of risk-weighted assets;
Minimum Tier 1 capital ratio: 7.5% of risk-weighted assets;

Domestically Systemically Important Banks (D-SIBs) shall maintain an additional Higher Loss Absorbency (HLA) surcharge of up to 2.0% of risk-weighted assets, as determined by SBP based on systemic importance assessment.

content.p: Risk-weighted assets shall be computed using the Standardized Approach for credit risk, the Basic Indicator Approach or Standardized Approach for operational risk, and the Standardized Measurement Method for market risk, as prescribed by SBP.

section.heading: Powers of SBP to issue directives, inspect, and penalize

content.p: The State Bank may, by order in writing:

item.p: cause an inspection to be made by one or more of its officers of any banking company and its books and accounts, and the banking company shall produce before the inspecting officer all such books, accounts, and other documents in its custody or power as may be required;

impose monetary penalties on a banking company for failure to comply with any direction, regulation, or provision of this Ordinance, subject to a maximum penalty of PKR 250,000,000 (two hundred and fifty million Pakistani Rupees) per contravention or such higher amount as may be prescribed;
require a banking company to convene a meeting of its board of directors to consider such matters as the State Bank may direct.

content.p: The State Bank shall, before imposing any penalty or removing any person under this section, give the banking company or person concerned a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

section.heading: Licensing by SBP required for all microfinance banks

content.p: No company shall carry on the business of a microfinance bank in Pakistan except under and in accordance with a licence issued by the State Bank of Pakistan under this Ordinance.
An application for a microfinance banking licence shall be accompanied by:

item.p: evidence of paid-up capital meeting the minimum prescribed under section 6;
a certified copy of the memorandum and articles of association;
particulars of directors and chief executive, with fit and proper declarations as prescribed by SBP;
a five-year business plan demonstrating the viability of the proposed microfinance operations and projected outreach;
details of the proposed AML/CFT compliance framework and internal audit arrangements.

content.p: The State Bank may refuse to grant a licence if it is not satisfied that the applicant has adequate capital, management capability, or compliance infrastructure to operate as a microfinance bank.

section.heading: Minimum paid-up capital for microfinance banks

content.p: The minimum paid-up capital (free of losses) for microfinance banks (MFBs), as revised by SBP circular of 2023:

item.p: District-level microfinance bank (operating within a single district or designated area): PKR 300,000,000 (three hundred million Pakistani Rupees).

content.p: Microfinance banks shall observe the following lending limits as prescribed by SBP Prudential Regulations for Microfinance Banks:

item.p: Group lending: maximum loan per group member PKR 500,000 (five hundred thousand Pakistani Rupees).

content.p: The aggregate exposure of an MFB to any single borrower or group of connected borrowers shall not exceed 10% of the bank's equity.
Every microfinance bank licensed under this Ordinance shall participate in the Deposit Protection Corporation (DPC) established by SBP for the protection of depositors.
MFB deposits are insured by the DPC up to a coverage limit of PKR 500,000 (five hundred thousand Pakistani Rupees) per depositor per bank, as notified by SBP.

Each MFB shall pay annual premiums to the DPC at the rate prescribed by SBP, computed as a percentage of the bank's assessed deposit base. The premium rate shall not exceed 0.16% of assessed deposits per annum.
The State Bank may, at any time, cause an inspection to be made by one or more of its officers of any microfinance bank and its books, accounts, and records.
The State Bank may:

item.p: require the production of books, accounts, and documents;
examine on oath any director, officer, or employee of the microfinance bank;
issue directives requiring the microfinance bank to take corrective action within a specified time;
impose penalties, suspend or cancel the licence, or require the microfinance bank to submit a recapitalization plan if capital falls below the prescribed minimum.

part.heading: Payment Systems and Electronic Fund Transfers Act, 2007 (Act V of 2007) and SBP Raast Regulations, 2021

section.heading: SBP authorization required for payment system operators

content.p: No person shall operate, or hold himself out as operating, a designated payment system except under and in accordance with an authorization granted by the State Bank under this Act.
An application for authorization shall contain:

item.p: the name, registered address, and legal form of the applicant;
a description of the payment system, its rules, and operating procedures;
evidence of minimum net worth as prescribed by SBP (currently PKR 200,000,000 for payment system operators);
the proposed risk management framework, including settlement risk and operational risk controls;
the applicant's AML/CFT compliance program.

content.p: A transfer order or netting that has been effected through a designated payment system shall be final and irrevocable upon settlement, and shall not be reversed, revoked, or set aside by any court, tribunal, or authority.
Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, including the insolvency or winding up of a participant:

item.p: settlement made through the Pakistan Real-time Interbank Settlement Mechanism (PRISM) or Raast shall be considered final upon confirmation by SBP.

section.heading: Real-time settlement through SBP Raast infrastructure

content.p: Raast is Pakistan's instant payment system developed and operated by the State Bank of Pakistan, providing real-time settlement of person-to-person (P2P), person-to-merchant (P2M), and bulk payment transactions.

All Raast transactions are settled in real-time through the SBP Raast infrastructure, with immediate and irrevocable credit to the beneficiary's account. Settlement finality is achieved at the moment of credit posting by the beneficiary institution.
Person-to-person (P2P) transfers through Raast are subject to the following limits (updated 2024):

item.p: All P2P transfers require the sender to be authenticated via the sending institution's mobile or internet banking application.

content.p: Person-to-merchant (P2M) transfers through Raast are not subject to a regulatory per-transaction maximum. However, the acquiring institution shall apply its own risk-based limits as part of its merchant risk management framework.
Merchant onboarding requirements:

item.p: The acquiring institution shall complete full KYC on each merchant, including verification of National Tax Number (NTN) or Computerized National Identity Card (CNIC), business registration certificate, and physical or virtual business address;
The acquiring institution shall assign a merchant category code (MCC) to each merchant in accordance with ISO 18245;

Ongoing transaction monitoring shall be performed by the acquiring institution to detect suspicious patterns, with reporting to the Financial Monitoring Unit (FMU) as required under the Anti-Money Laundering Act, 2010.

content.p: Participation in the Raast Instant Payment System (IPS) is restricted to:

item.p: scheduled commercial banks licensed by SBP under the Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962;
microfinance banks licensed by SBP under the Microfinance Institutions Ordinance, 2001;
Electronic Money Institutions (EMIs) licensed by SBP under the EMI Regulations, 2019;
Government entities designated by SBP for bulk disbursement purposes.

content.p: Each participant must execute the Raast Participation Agreement, meet technical integration requirements, and pass SBP certification testing before going live on the Raast network.
All Raast transactions shall use the ISO 20022 message format. The following message types are mandatory:

item.p: pain.013 — CreditorPaymentActivationRequest: used for request-to-pay messages in P2M use cases;
camt.053 — BankToCustomerStatement: used for reconciliation and account reporting purposes.

content.p: All participants shall conform to the Raast ISO 20022 Message Implementation Guide published by SBP. Non-conforming messages shall be rejected by the Raast clearing and settlement infrastructure.

part.heading: SBP Regulations for Electronic Money Institutions, 2019

content.p: No entity shall issue electronic money, operate e-money wallets, or provide e-money services in Pakistan except under and in accordance with a licence granted by the State Bank of Pakistan under these Regulations.
An EMI licence may be granted as:

item.p: Restricted EMI licence: limited to specific e-money services as determined by SBP on a case-by-case basis.

content.p: An entity applying for a full EMI licence shall maintain a minimum paid-up capital of PKR 200,000,000 (two hundred million Pakistani Rupees), free of losses, at all times.

The minimum paid-up capital for a restricted EMI licence shall be determined by SBP based on the scope of authorized services, but shall not be less than PKR 50,000,000 (fifty million Pakistani Rupees).
EMI wallets are tiered based on KYC level. The following limits apply:

item.p: Level 0 (minimum KYC — CNIC only): maximum single transaction PKR 25,000; monthly aggregate outflow PKR 200,000; maximum wallet balance PKR 200,000;
Level 1 (biometric verification via NADRA): maximum single transaction PKR 50,000; monthly aggregate outflow PKR 400,000; maximum wallet balance PKR 400,000;
Level 2 (full CDD — enhanced due diligence): maximum wallet balance PKR 500,000 (five hundred thousand Pakistani Rupees); monthly throughput PKR 1,000,000 (one million Pakistani Rupees).

content.p: All EMI accounts must be linked to a valid Computerized National Identity Card (CNIC) issued by the National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA). For Level 1 and above, biometric verification against the NADRA database is mandatory at the time of account opening.
EMIs may appoint agents for cash-in and cash-out services subject to the following requirements:

item.p: Each agent must be a person with a valid CNIC and a fixed business premises, or a corporate entity registered in Pakistan;
The EMI shall perform due diligence on each agent before onboarding, including verification of identity, business history, and financial standing;
Agent transactions shall be subject to the same per-transaction and aggregate limits applicable to the customer's wallet tier;
Agent float shall be maintained separately from the EMI's operational funds and customer e-money float.

content.p: The EMI shall safeguard customer funds as follows:

item.p: All customer e-money funds (the float) shall be deposited in a trust account maintained with one or more scheduled commercial banks licensed by SBP;
The EMI shall not use customer float for its own operational expenses, lending, or investment purposes beyond the permitted liquid asset classes;
The trust account shall be audited quarterly by an external auditor, and the audit report shall be submitted to SBP within 30 days of the quarter end.

part.heading: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 (Act VII of 1947)

content.p: All foreign exchange transactions in Pakistan shall be conducted through authorized dealers, being banks or other entities licensed by the State Bank of Pakistan to deal in foreign exchange.
No person other than an authorized dealer shall:

item.p: buy, sell, borrow, or lend foreign exchange;
make any payment to or for the credit of any person resident outside Pakistan;
receive any payment from or on behalf of any person resident outside Pakistan, otherwise than through an authorized dealer or with the prior permission of SBP.

content.p: Exchange companies licensed by SBP may conduct limited foreign currency purchase and sale transactions for the purpose of facilitating inward remittances and currency exchange for travel purposes, subject to SBP-prescribed limits.
The following capital account transactions require prior approval of SBP:

item.p: Outward remittances by individuals exceeding USD 10,000 (ten thousand United States Dollars) per calendar year, including remittances for education, medical treatment, gifts, and donations;
Direct investment abroad by Pakistani residents;
Acquisition or transfer of immovable property outside Pakistan;
Borrowing from non-residents or lending to non-residents;
Opening or maintaining bank accounts outside Pakistan, except as permitted by SBP for specific purposes (e.g., diplomatic staff, students abroad).

content.p: Inward remittances, including worker remittances and foreign direct investment, are generally permitted through authorized channels without prior SBP approval, subject to reporting requirements.
Every exporter shall ensure that the full export proceeds are received in Pakistan through an authorized dealer within 120 days from the date of shipment.
Where export proceeds are not received within the prescribed period, the authorized dealer shall report the overdue amount to SBP, and the exporter shall be liable to:

item.p: a penalty not exceeding 30% of the overdue amount, as may be imposed by SBP;
suspension of further export facilities until the overdue amount is received or written off with SBP approval;
referral to the Federal Investigation Agency (FIA) for investigation if foreign exchange regulation violations are suspected.

content.p: SBP may grant extensions beyond 120 days in exceptional circumstances, including force majeure, contractual disputes, and country risk events, subject to documented application by the exporter through the authorized dealer.

section.heading: Penalties for unauthorized foreign exchange dealing

content.p: Any person who contravenes any provision of this Act or any rule, regulation, direction, or order made thereunder shall be liable to:

item.p: Criminal prosecution under section 23-A, punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both, where the contravention involves hawala/hundi transactions or systematic evasion of exchange control regulations;
Confiscation of any foreign exchange, securities, or property involved in or derived from the contravention.

content.p: The State Bank may, in addition to or in lieu of the penalties specified above, cancel or suspend the authorization of any authorized dealer or exchange company found to have contravened this Act.
